snippet: Though the state has suspended $60 million from the federal government to pay for programs already under way at troubled schools, those schools have been told to forge ahead.
abstract: New York City Education Dept tells principals in 33 of its most troubled schools to stay the course in carrying out improvement plans despite the state's suspension of federal school improvement grants; city has asked state to determine whether rules governing the grants might allow the money to be restored some other way.

byline.original: By FERNANDA SANTOS and ANNA M. PHILLIPS

lead_paragraph: Though the state has suspended $60 million from the federal government to pay for programs already under way at troubled schools, those schools have been told to forge ahead.

headline.seo: Grants in Limbo, New York City Tells Principals to Forge Ahead
headline.main: Grants in Limbo, the City Tells Principals to Hold On
headline.print_headline: Grants in Limbo, the City Tells Principals to Hold On
